text: the Falkland Islands or even a vides are
an archipelago of 740 islands in the
South Atlantic with rugged terrain cliff
line coasts and spectacular wildlife
they are one of the most remote islands
in the world and I spent the last three
days here on our Hurtigruten expedition
up until this morning I thought the
Falcons are only natural landscapes and
wildlife which don't get me wrong
there's plenty of stunning beauty here
but after spending all day tuning around
the main town of Stanley just walking
around Stanley starting the day I
quickly learned that a civilization does
exist thank you there are about 22
hundred residents in Stanley alone and
roughly 3,300 in the entire country to
me Stanley feels like a small village in
England even though I'm more than eight
thousand miles from the United Kingdom
and that's because the vast majority of
Falkland heirs are descendants of
British settlers who first came here in
the early 19th century the currency is a
falcon highland pound which only works
here
they speak British English with even a
thicker accent than you can imagine
they love fish and chips and there are
several pubs where you can grab a pint
of local beer I mean look how British
this pub is their flag has a small
British flag in the corner there are
double decker red buses they have red
telephone booths they drive on the left
side of the road and their license
plates look like this I didn't notice
any traces of an indigenous culture
Stanley is one of the smallest capitals
in the world there is one bank with no
ATMs and one newspaper called the
penguin news there are no McDonald's no
Starbucks or any other recognizable
chains the streets are narrow with no
advertisements or traffic lights because
traffic simply doesn't exist that being
said I did see a variety of supermarkets
souvenir shop restaurants tourist
centres and I heard there's even a golf
course it's quite interesting if you ask
me as you can see it's an extremely
peaceful life here in the Balkans and
the people are very kind
welcome to Copeland Islands but on the
other hand the politics are not so
peaceful the sovereignty of the Falkland
Islands is an ongoing dispute between
the United Kingdom and nearby Argentina
here's a short history recap Britain
established rule here in 1833 but
Argentina has always maintained claim to
the islands as they're just 500
kilometres east of there short on April
2nd 1982 a war broke out
Argentina invaded and occupied the
Falklands in South Georgia three days
later the British showed up on ships and
fought a bloody battle over ten weeks
mostly on these mountains that killed
nearly a thousand people and ultimately
left Argentina surrendering in a 2013
referendum 99.8% of Falklands voted to
remain a British territory overseas
since they are mostly descendants of the
British how many generation Falkland are
you five
oh I'm four my sons are five generations
and I'm a native what is my country I
don't belong but a conflict still exists
with Argentina today anyways let's talk
more about the culture because I find it
fascinating I already told you how
British it feels here in Stanley but
let's take a look deeper what kind of
jobs do false wonders have well lots
since unemployment is less than 1% but
most jobs are seasonal like growing
vegetables and sheets being to make and
sell wool there are a hundred and sixty
sheep for every one person many others
have governmental jobs like working in
the airport at the City Council or as a
public school teacher the Falkland
Islands are truly one of the most
interesting places i've ever visited and
I enjoyed every minute I spent here I
hope you get the chance to visit some
day and see what it's like later
I'm drew pinsky and if you like my
travel videos please click Subscribe and
join me as I plan to visit every country
in the world
